subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Interesting article
msgSnippet: ... My main issue is that the Latin alphabet is space and time consuming for *any* language.  I use Melins Swedish shorthand system for personal note taking
messageBody:
Paige Gabhart skrev:
> Benct:
>
> Thanks for the interesting article. I haven't had time to get through
> it all, but I will. I've saved a copy on my computer.
>
> Also: forgive my ignorance of Swedish, but are the problems with its
> phoneme to grapheme correspondence sufficiently severe to justify
> revising its alphabet?

My main issue is that the Latin alphabet is space and time
consuming for *any* language. I use Melins Swedish
shorthand system for personal note taking since many years,
and while I am by no means up to the standards of a report
or even dictation stenographer I still write faster in
shorthand than in longhand. However shorthand is not really
space conserving if written in a relaxed way, and although
it is fast to write it is not particularly fast to read,
especially when you read shorthand written by someone else!
That's why I'm interested in Quikscript, and in adapting it
to Swedish. The main problem is that Swedish has eightteen
vowel phonemes -- if you mark vowel length, as you must do
in Quikscript, since consonant doubling is not really an
option there -- but Quikscript really has only fifteen
or sixteen good vowel letters, since I want to use only
"short" letters for vowels.
--
/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch at melroch dot se

"Maybe" is a strange word. When mum or dad says it
it means "yes", but when my big brothers say it it
means "no"!

(Philip Jonsson jr, age 7)
